Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Kinematics of Quadrupedal Locomotion in Free-Ranging Primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of primate species are partially or completely tree-dwelling (arboreal), and they often captivate observers with their ability to walk and run with ease over narrow, steep, and bending branches. The goal of this project is to investigate the mechanics of quadrupedal locomotion (movement on four limbs) in wild primates moving in their natural environments, to provide a deeper understanding of primate arboreal athleticism. Past studies of primate quadrupedal mechanics have largely come from laboratory-based research, but in this study researchers will use advanced and durable video technologies that permit high-resolution measures of locomotion in the wild. The results of this project will further our understanding of locomotor adaptations that are thought to be central to the evolution of our early primate ancestors. The project will support undergraduate and graduate student training, and will enhance K-12 STEM education and public outreach through high school programs and collaborations with established science outreach programs at UT Austin. Findings from this project will be relevant to primate conservation efforts, science education, and community outreach at the field location.

This project will test hypotheses about the proximate and ultimate determinants of primate locomotor adaptation through analysis of ten free-ranging New World monkey species at the Tiputini Biodiversity Station in Ecuador. The investigators will document the locomotor kinematics of quadrupedal primates moving in their natural habitats using multi-camera, high-speed, high-resolution videography, sampling arboreal locomotion on a range of substrates and quantifying standard kinematic spatiotemporal variables. The morphology of the arboreal locomotor substrates will be quantified using novel methods, with specific measurements including substrate diameter, three-dimensional substrate orientation, substrate height above the ground, and substrate compliance. By analyzing the determinants of kinematic variation in an explicit phylogenetic framework, researchers will explore historical, allometric, and functional influences on primate quadrupedalism. This research will add to existing laboratory and field data, breaking new ground by lending ecological validity to standard metrics of gait performance and increasing the precision of standard field measurements of kinematics and substrate variation. The comparative phylogenetic framework will allow "field" testing of functional associations between kinematic features and aspects of substrate variation that have been previously demonstrated only in laboratory studies. Such knowledge is critical to understanding the adaptive context in which the distinctive aspects of primate quadrupedalism evolved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability of primates to successfully move through the trees has played a key role in their evolutionary success. Although primates have evolved a variety of locomotor styles to meet these challenges, quadrupedalism (moving on all four limbs) was a key adaptation in our earliest primate ancestors and continues to be used by most living primates. Decades of research have revealed comparatively unique ways that primates keep their balance when walking or running, but these studies have mainly been conducted in lab settings, filming primates moving on poles or simulated branches. Until now, it has been unclear whether primates? locomotor behavior in the lab is representative of their natural behavior, because it is difficult if not impossible to recreate the complex environmental conditions that might have been key in producing their unique locomotor adaptations. The goal of this project was to bring technological methods previously only available in lab settings to the natural habitats of primates, providing the raw data needed to study how primates have evolved to navigate the complex variety of branches, lianas and other vegetation they encounter when moving through the trees.

We collected over >3,000 high-speed videos across eleven species of New World monkeys (platyrrhines) at Tiputini Biodiversity Station in Ecuador and the La Suerte Biological Field Station in Costa Rica and quantified branch diameter, orientation and flexibility using photography, remote sensing, and force gauges. One of the most unusual aspects of primate quadrupedalism is the order in which they move their limbs when walking and running (i.e., gait patterns), and there has been much lab-based research dedicated to discerning which aspects of the arboreal environment (e.g. branch size, orientation) might have led to the evolution of primate gait patterns. Our field data generally corroborate laboratory studies but capture additional aspects of gait variability and flexibility in response to the complexity of natural environments. Overall, our results suggest that primate gait patterns are not exclusively tailored to narrow or oblique substrates but are used across a variety of supports. Additionally, we found significant differences in gait patterns among the major platyrrhine groups, suggesting that evolutionary history may be a better predictor of gait than substrate diameter or orientation. For example, sakis and titi monkeys frequently use walking gait patterns unlike those preferred by other monkeys. In addition, the very small-bodied marmosets and tamarins are distinct from other New World monkeys in their frequent use of galloping and bounding, a pattern that seems to be closely tied to their preference for large branches and tree trunks, where these relatively unstable gaits are less risky.  Our study also revealed ways in which primates continuously adapt their quadrupedal locomotion to complex natural environments. For instance, we analyzed how primates make instantaneous adjustments to locomotion when encountering gaps and other obstacles in their path during traversals through the complex arboreal habitat. Thus far, we have found that a representative small-bodied species (squirrel monkeys) makes significant mechanical changes when encountering obstacles in its path whereas a representative large species (i.e., woolly monkeys) does not adjust its gait.  Additionally, we have undertaken some of the first analyses of how primates adjust their gait in response to support compliance (i.e., ?bendiness?), finding that larger species preferentially select stiffer supports in the natural environment, likely promoting stability. Our methods and data have also provided insight on the locomotion of wild arboreal squirrels and on the ankle morphology of New World monkeys and fossil primates. Our field methodological techniques have been published as a user?s guide to aid other researchers in quantifying primate locomotion and habitat structure in wild habitats. Overall, our results highlight the utility of these techniques for understanding both the proximate environmental and broader evolutionary determinants of primate locomotion.

This project has resulted in 6 peer reviewed publications, with an additional 3 in preparation, and 12 professional presentations. At the University of Texas at Austin, it has provided training and mentorship for a graduate student and 9 undergraduate students (including a UT Austin student recruited through a program that targets first-generation students and students from underrepresented groups). The graduate student was awarded a student prize at a national conference for research funded by the project, and also participated in the Scientist in Residence program through UT Austin's Environmental Science Institute (ESI), partnering with local K-12 science teachers in the classroom to develop innovative science learning activities, including those related to this project. At NEOMED, project funds supported the training of a postdoctoral research fellow who has gone on to successfully obtain a research staff position at a zoological park. The NEOMED PI taught three short courses on primate biodiversity and biomechanics at a local STEM high school affiliated with the university. Gait analysis software developed for this project is now freely available online for other researchers to use (http://web.neomed.edu/web/anatomy/Young/GaitKeeper/;  http://web.neomed.edu/web/anatomy/Young/Boutkeeper/).

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2020
Modified by: Liza J Shapiro
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The ability of primates to successfully move through the trees has played a key role in their evolutionary success. Although primates have evolved a variety of locomotor styles to meet these challenges, quadrupedalism (moving on all four limbs) was a key adaptation in our earliest primate ancestors and continues to be used by most living primates. Decades of research have revealed comparatively unique ways that primates keep their balance when walking or running, but these studies have mainly been conducted in lab settings, filming primates moving on poles or simulated branches. Until now, it has been unclear whether primates? locomotor behavior in the lab is representative of their natural behavior, because it is difficult if not impossible to recreate the complex environmental conditions that might have been key in producing their unique locomotor adaptations. The goal of this project was to bring technological methods previously only available in lab settings to the natural habitats of primates, providing the raw data needed to study how primates have evolved to navigate the complex variety of branches, lianas and other vegetation they encounter when moving through the trees. We collected over >3,000 high-speed videos across eleven species of New World monkeys (platyrrhines) at Tiputini Biodiversity Station in Ecuador and the La Suerte Biological Field Station in Costa Rica and quantified branch diameter, orientation and flexibility using photography, remote sensing, and force gauges. One of the most unusual aspects of primate quadrupedalism is the order in which they move their limbs when walking and running (i.e., gait patterns), and there has been much lab-based research dedicated to discerning which aspects of the arboreal environment (e.g. branch size, orientation) might have led to the evolution of primate gait patterns. Our field data generally corroborate laboratory studies but capture additional aspects of gait variability and flexibility in response to the complexity of natural environments. Overall, our results suggest that primate gait patterns are not exclusively tailored to narrow or oblique substrates but are used across a variety of supports. Additionally, we found significant differences in gait patterns among the major platyrrhine groups, suggesting that evolutionary history may be a better predictor of gait than substrate diameter or orientation. For example, sakis and titi monkeys frequently use walking gait patterns unlike those preferred by other monkeys. In addition, the very small-bodied marmosets and tamarins are distinct from other New World monkeys in their frequent use of galloping and bounding, a pattern that seems to be closely tied to their preference for large branches and tree trunks, where these relatively unstable gaits are less risky. Our study also revealed ways in which primates continuously adapt their quadrupedal locomotion to complex natural environments. For instance, we analyzed how primates make instantaneous adjustments to locomotion when encountering gaps and other obstacles in their path during traversals through the complex arboreal habitat. Thus far, we have found that a representative small-bodied species (squirrel monkeys) makes significant mechanical changes when encountering obstacles in its path whereas a representative large species (i.e., woolly monkeys) does not adjust its gait. Additionally, we have undertaken some of the first analyses of how primates adjust their gait in response to support compliance (i.e., ?bendiness?), finding that larger species preferentially select stiffer supports in the natural environment, likely promoting stability. Our methods and data have also provided insight on the locomotion of wild arboreal squirrels and on the ankle morphology of New World monkeys and fossil primates. Our field methodological techniques have been published as a user?s guide to aid other researchers in quantifying primate locomotion and habitat structure in wild habitats. Overall, our results highlight the utility of these techniques for understanding both the proximate environmental and broader evolutionary determinants of primate locomotion. This project has resulted in 6 peer reviewed publications, with an additional 3 in preparation, and 12 professional presentations. At the University of Texas at Austin, it has provided training and mentorship for a graduate student and 9 undergraduate students (including a UT Austin student recruited through a program that targets first-generation students and students from underrepresented groups). The graduate student was awarded a student prize at a national conference for research funded by the project, and also participated in the Scientist in Residence program through UT Austin's Environmental Science Institute (ESI), partnering with local K-12 science teachers in the classroom to develop innovative science learning activities, including those related to this project. At NEOMED, project funds supported the training of a postdoctoral research fellow who has gone on to successfully obtain a research staff position at a zoological park. The NEOMED PI taught three short courses on primate biodiversity and biomechanics at a local STEM high school affiliated with the university. Gait analysis software developed for this project is now freely available online for other researchers to use (http://web.neomed.edu/web/anatomy/Young/GaitKeeper/; http://web.neomed.edu/web/anatomy/Young/Boutkeeper/).
